text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
HET FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- ING bank will hold on to disposables maker De Ster for at least another five years. (p1)
- More than half a million tonnes of copper stored in Rotterdam port not included in London Metal Exchange's offical copper reserve figures, says World Bureau of Metal Statistics. (p1)
- Schiphol Airport and cable operator Casema would be on investors' wish list if they were to be launched on the bourse according to a study. (p1)
- Unions and employers in Amsterdam and Rotterdam port are nearing agreement on social plan proposing to rejuvenate work force. (p1)
- Insurer Stad Rotterdam books 15.6 pct higher profit in first nine months at Dfl 103.2 million. (p3)
- Dairy cooperation Friesland Dairy Foods enters the Colombian market. (p3)
- Food group unit retailer services company Vendex to present new type of supermarket. (p3)
- Office furniture and supplies group Samas posts flat first half net on 12 pct higher turnover. (p5)
DE VOLKSKRANT
- New confrontation between France and the Netherlands threatens about Dutch drugs policy. (p1)
- Korea's Samsung seems unable to interest other Korean companies to cooperate in taking over bankrupt aircraft maker Fokker. (p1)
- Germany's central bank president Hans Tietmeyer praises Dutch economic policy. (p2)
- Aluminium processing companies Billiton and Alcoa seek to put an end to strikes in Surinam. (p9)
DE TELEGRAAF
- Inquiry into BolsWessanen insider trading case handed over to examining magistrate. (p29)
- Nedschroef seeks to sell its U.S. subsidiary Nedschroef Corporation in Houston, Texas. (p29)
- Investment company Wolters Holding brings back its stake in Goudsmit from 63.9 pct to 19.4 pct. (p29)
- Philips Electronics drops from first to 28th place on list of best investor relations. (p29)
TROUW
- Dutch cable operators association Vecai rejects contract with sports-only commercial TV station Sport7. (p3)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Cabinet seeks to curb government auditor office's authority. (p1)
- Staff of container shipment company ECT holds a wild cat strike to pressure for clarity on company's future. (p13)
--Amsterdam newsdesk +31-20-504-5000
